Package gnu.cajo.invoke

This package is the foundation for completely transparent local/remote inter-VM communication.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Invoke The generic inter-component communication interface, and foundation for this paradigm.
RemoteInvoke The Remote Component Communication Interface, and reason for this package.
 

Class Summary
Client This class is used to create a hosting VM to receive graphical proxy objects, from remote VMs.
NoSecurityManager This utility class creates a trivial SecurityManager for developing proxy hosting clients.
Remote This class takes any object, and allows it to be called from remote VMs.
 

Package gnu.cajo.invoke Description

This package is the foundation for completely transparent local/remote inter-VM communication. It provides a standard interface between local/remote objects, and prevents having to generate unique RMI stubs for every application specific class.

The rationale behind this paradim is to enable seamless and dynamic linking between remote and local objects; in order to accomplish advanced functionality. Objects can also be mobile, i.e. moving from one VM to another, even providing graphical user interfaces to itself, on remote hosts. Objects can even be dynamically linked, with objects from other applications, at runtime. This can support, and harness, such concepts as scale-free networking, and the emergent phenomena of collective networking.

For the purposes of this paradigm, any object implementing the Invoke interface is considered an Item. If a VM allows the loading of mobile code, and an item is sent to it, either as an argument, or a return value, that item is referred to as a Proxy, in this architecture.

This package is required be in the classpath of all clients, and therefore would never be included in a proxy's codebase jar file. This is done to both reduce the proxy's codebase size, and create a level of development standardization.

Also included in the package is a Client Application/Applet. While strictly non topical to this package, it provides another standard paradigm for creating, hosting, and using graphical proxy items. It could be likened to a next-generation X-client, but is far more capable, being able to perform application specific server computation at the client.
